channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 The New York Times Company

item.title: Archbishop of Canterbury Resigns Over U.K. Church Abuse Scandal
item.description: Justin Welby, the leader of 85 million Anglicans worldwide, announced his resignation days after a report found he had taken insufficient action over claims of abuse.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle and Mark Landler
item.media:credit: Mary Turner for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Most Rev. Justin Welby, archbishop of Canterbury, in London, last year. He has held his position since 2013, and was scheduled to retire in 2026.

item.title: A Former Harrods Employee Accuses Al-Fayed of Trafficking and Says His Brother Knew
item.description: In a U.S. court filing, a former employee says she was trafficked, raped and abused when Mohamed al-Fayed owned Harrods, and that his brother Ali may have evidence of the abuse.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia and Emily Steel
item.media:description: Ali Fayed, the younger brother of Mohamed al-Fayed, in 1989. Now 80, he has a property in Connecticut and is the chairman of a luxury British shirt maker.

item.title: Mexico Signals It Could Hit Back With Tariffs at U.S.
item.description: Could a tariff war erupt between the United States and Mexico? A top Mexican official said his country might retaliate if the Trump administration placed steep tariffs on Mexico.
item.dc:creator: Simon Romero and Emiliano Rodríguez Mega
item.media:description: Trucks waiting in April in Ciudad Juárez, Mexico, to cross into the United States.

item.title: The UK’s Award-Winning Centenary Building May be Reduced to Rubble
item.description: A building, once celebrated for its innovation, is deemed obsolete. Those trying to save it ask what its demolition means for British architecture.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel

item.title: Germany Will Hold Snap Election in February
item.description: After the collapse of Chancellor Olaf Scholz’s governing coalition, the balloting will be held on Feb. 23, about seven months before it had been scheduled.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:description: The German Bundestag in Berlin.

item.title: Israel’s Bloody Cycle of War Against Hamas Returns to North Gaza
item.description: Israel said its forces had returned to northern Gaza to fight a Hamas resurgence. That has brought a new round of suffering for residents.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas, Adam Rasgon and Hiba Yazbek
item.media:description: A Palestinian woman lost her leg when her family home was destroyed in the Jabaliya refugee camp in northern Gaza last week.

item.title: Its Birthrate Falling, Russia Targets Child-Free Lifestyles
item.description: The country’s lower house of Parliament passed a law that would ban what it calls “propaganda” discouraging Russians from having children.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: Walking on Red Square in Moscow in 2022. A bill passed by lawmakers would ban materials promoting the “conscious refusal to have children” for Russians.

item.title: Amsterdam Authorities Expect More Arrests Related to Attacks Around Soccer Match
item.description: So far, 62 people have been detained in connection with unrest surrounding a soccer match as officials said they continue to investigate antisemitic attacks, as well as incendiary behavior by both sides.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze, Jim Tankersley and Rosanne Kropman
item.media:description: Police officers in Amsterdam on Saturday. Extra security measures were put in place in the city after clashes involving supporters of the soccer club Maccabi Tel Aviv.

item.title: Italian City in Amanda Knox Case Wants to Move On. A New Series Won’t Let It.
item.description: When a show produced by Ms. Knox about the murder of Meredith Kercher was filmed in Perugia, an outcry by residents led the mayor to apologize.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:description: One local councilor in Perugia, Italy, said the continued focus on the killing distracted from the city’s “history, art and beauty.”

item.title: Russian Doctor, Accused of Antiwar Stance, Is Jailed After Child’s Testimony
item.description: The mother of a 7-year-old boy accused the Moscow pediatrician, Nadezhda Buyanova, of telling him that his father’s death while fighting in Ukraine was justified.
item.dc:creator: Nataliya Vasilyeva
item.media:description: Nadezhda Buyanova, left, a pediatrician charged with spreading false information about Russia’s army, in court in Moscow last week.

item.title: Russia and Iran Vie for Influence in the Caucasus Region
item.description: In the volatile Caucasus region, Russia and Iran, often seen as united in their aims, are vying to secure trade routes and influence. That leaves Western countries facing an unusual dilemma.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski and Emile Ducke
item.media:credit: Emile Ducke for The New York Times

item.title: Israel Intensifies Strikes in Lebanon Amid Push for Cease-Fire
item.description: The conflict between Israel and Hezbollah has deepened in recent days despite diplomatic efforts to move toward a temporary truce.
item.dc:creator: Euan Ward and Jack Nicas

item.title: Hanako Okada Beat the Odds to Upend a Male Political Dynasty in Japan
item.description: Hanako Okada was one of 73 women to win seats at the general election last month, a record number in a Parliament long dominated by men.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich and Kiuko Notoya
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: Hanako Okada was elected at the House of Representatives for a district of Aomori in Japan, a country with one of the worst records of giving women political power.

item.title: Iran Debates Whether It Could Make a Deal With Trump
item.description: Some in Iran’s new, more moderate government think the result of the presidential election provides an opportunity to make a lasting deal with the United States.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Reading a story about the election of Donald J. Trump in Tehran on Thursday.

item.title: At COP29, Keir Starmer Announces the UK’s Ambitious Climate Targets
item.description: The prime minister announced more ambitious climate targets, charting a very different course from the United States, which is expected to roll back its energy transition plans.
item.dc:creator: Somini Sengupta
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:description: Prime Minister Keir Starmer of Britain at the United Nations climate conference in Baku, Azerbaijan, on Tuesday.

item.title: Exxon Chief to Trump: Don’t Withdraw From Paris Climate Deal
item.description: Darren Woods was one of only a few Western oil executives attending a global climate conference in Baku, Azerbaijan.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca F. Elliott
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change

item.title: Blinken Heads to NATO as Alliance Prepares for Trump’s Return
item.description: Officials meeting in Brussels will discuss Ukraine’s war against Russia amid concerns that the new administration will slash U.S. support for Kyiv.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley
item.media:description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken will meet NATO and E.U. counterparts “to discuss support for Ukraine in its defense against Russia’s aggression,” the State Department said.

item.title: Sharath Jois, Heir to Founder of Ashtanga Yoga, Dies at 53
item.description: He became one of the world’s most sought-after teachers of a style of yoga that his grandfather helped turn into a popular form of exercise worldwide.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon
item.media:description: Sharath Jois at the University of Virginia on Monday, where he was teaching yoga instructors from around the world.

item.title: Gary Lineker to Leave BBC’s ‘Match of the Day’
item.description: After a 26-year run, the voice of the broadcaster’s popular soccer highlights show will leave at the end of the 2025 season, the network said Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: Ali Watkins
item.media:description: Gary Lineker in 2021. He will continue to work on other BBC shows.

item.title: Man Drives Car Into Crowd in Southern China, Killing at Least 35
item.description: The police in the city of Zhuhai detained a man who they said had rammed a small vehicle into people who were exercising at a sports center.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Stevenson, Zixu Wang and Muyi Xiao
item.media:description: People gathered near a sports center in Zhuhai, China, on Monday after a man drove into people exercising there.

item.title: Biden Officials Try to Reassure COP29 Climate Talks
item.description: Negotiators at the summit in Azerbaijan fear that the return of Donald Trump will sap momentum for global climate action.
item.dc:creator: Brad Plumer and David Gelles
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:description: World leaders at the COP29 climate summit in Baku, Azerbaijan, on Tuesday, the first day of high-level meetings.

item.title: Countries Weigh How to Raise Trillions for Climate Crisis at COP29
item.description: Low-income countries need at least $1 trillion a year to manage climate change. Donald Trump’s victory just made that more difficult, but options exist.
item.dc:creator: Somini Sengupta and Lydia DePillis

item.title: Tuesday Briefing
item.description: Key figures in the next Trump administration.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Senator Marco Rubio is expected to be named the next secretary of state.

item.title: ‘We Welcomed Them’: G.O.P. Embraces New Latino Voters in Arizona
item.description: Days ago, President-elect Donald J. Trump won swing-state Arizona, flipping the state back to red.
item.dc:creator: Alex Pena
item.media:credit: Stephanie Figgins for The New York Times

item.title: I.C.C. Prosecutor Seeking Arrest of Israeli Leaders Faces Own Inquiry
item.description: The International Criminal Court said there will be an investigation into sexual misconduct allegations against Karim Khan, the court’s chief prosecutor.
item.dc:creator: Eve Sampson
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: Karim Khan, the International Criminal Court’s chief prosecutor, in Paris in February.

item.title: Amsterdam Police Arrest 5 More Men Over Antisemitic Attacks
item.description: A total of eight people were being held in connection with last week’s violence, and unrest in the largest city in the Netherlands continued on Monday night.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses and Jenny Gross
item.media:description: Police officers stationed on Thursday in Amsterdam near the soccer match between Maccabi Tel Aviv, an Israeli team, and Ajax, a Dutch team.

item.title: Tuesday Briefing: Trump Starts Building His Cabinet
item.description: Plus, West African fine dining.
item.dc:creator: Gaya Gupta
item.media:description: Representative Elise Stefanik was asked to be the U.N. ambassador.

item.title: Bishop Calls on Anglican Leader to Quit Over Handling of Abuse Scandal
item.description: An independent report last week said that Justin Welby, the archbishop of Canterbury, took insufficient action after learning of alleged abuse decades ago at Christian summer camps.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:credit: Mary Turner for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Most Rev. Justin Welby, archbishop of Canterbury, in London last year, has held his position since 2013 and is scheduled to retire in 2026.

item.title: Netanyahu Seeks to Delay Testifying at His Corruption Trial
item.description: Benjamin Netanyahu, the Israeli prime minister, is on trial for bribery and fraud. Now he wants to delay giving testimony.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley and Ronen Bergman
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu speaking at an army base near Mitzpe Ramon, Israel, in October.

item.title: Hama Amadou, West African Political ‘Phoenix,’ Dies at 74
item.description: An embattled leader for decades in Niger’s rough-and-tumble politics, he alternated stints in high office with prison and exile.
item.dc:creator: Adam Nossiter
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat

item.title: Jamie Oliver Pulls Children’s Book Amid Criticism of Insensitivity
item.description: The celebrity chef’s second children’s book, “Billy and the Epic Escape,” faced accusations that it stereotyped First Nations people in Australia.
item.dc:creator: Ali Watkins
item.media:description: Jamie Oliver said he was “devastated to have caused offense” with his children’s book.

item.title: Israel Calls for New Lebanon Evacuations as Cease-Fire Talks Ramp Up
item.description: The widespread orders across southern Lebanon came amid what appeared to be intensifying efforts to reach a cease-fire.
item.dc:creator: Euan Ward and Isabel Kershner
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Residents inspected the aftermath of a deadly airstrike on Almat, a town in the Jbeil district of Lebanon, north of Beirut, on Monday.

item.title: Iran and Trump Are Front of Mind at Muslim Summit in Saudi Arabia
item.description: Leaders from across the Arab and Muslim world were in Riyadh for a meeting officially convened to discuss the fighting in Gaza and Lebanon.
item.dc:creator: Ismaeel Naar
item.media:credit: Turkish Presidential Press Office/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Arab leaders gathering for meetings in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, on Monday in a photo provided by the Turkish Presidential Press Office.

item.title: Israel’s Military Announces Small Expansion of Gaza Humanitarian Zone
item.description: The move comes just before a Biden administration deadline for Israel to deliver more aid to the enclave or risk a cutoff of military supplies.
item.dc:creator: Hiba Yazbek
item.media:description: Lining up for meals cooked by a charity kitchen in Deir al Balah, in central Gaza, on Sunday.

item.title: Caught Between Wars, Syrian Refugees in Lebanon Return Home
item.description: Hundreds of thousands of Syrians who escaped civil war at home over the past decade have now fled the conflict in Lebanon, seeking safety in their own shattered country.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: The children of Mohammed Najjar (not pictured) and his sister-in-law riding in a bus back to their hometown in Syria after fleeing Lebanon.

item.title: How a Colombian Influencer Made Recycling Cool
item.description: The character Marce the Recycler has created an enthusiastic dedication to proper waste separation among her devoted fans.
item.dc:creator: Genevieve Glatsky and Nathalia Angarita
item.media:credit: Nathalia Angarita for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sara Samaniego records herself making a video in a recycling warehouse in Bogotá.Her recycling videos have drawn many viewers on social media.

item.title: Shigeru Ishiba Wins Vote to Remain as Japan’s Prime Minister
item.description: Parliament voted Monday to stick with Mr. Ishiba, who will lead a minority government after his party suffered heavy losses in an election last month.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich and Hisako Ueno
item.media:description: Shigeru Ishiba, standing, after winning a vote on Monday that will let him stay as Japan’s prime minister.

item.title: Chinese Students Went on Mass Night Bike Rides. Officials Shut Them Down.
item.description: Making the impromptu five-hour ride between two Chinese cities became a craze among young people. But as their numbers swelled, the authorities shut it down.
item.dc:creator: Isabelle Qian and Yan Zhuang
item.media:description: The students rode from the city of Zhengzhou, in Henan Province, to the neighboring city of Kaifeng. At first they were welcomed, but their large numbers soon raised safety concerns.

item.title: Monday Briefing
item.description: What Trump means for the Middle East.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: A billboard congratulating Donald Trump in Tel Aviv last week.

item.title: Will Trump Rekindle a Bromance With Kim Jong-un? South Koreans Worry.
item.description: Donald J. Trump’s second term brings uncertainty to the Korean Peninsula as nuclear tensions run high. North Korea’s leader may see a chance to re-engage.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: President Donald J. Trump and North Korea’s leader, Kim Jong-un, met for the first time in 2018 on Sentosa Island in Singapore.

item.title: Why Is COP29 Being Held in Baku, Azerbaijan?
item.description: The economy of Azerbaijan, host of COP29, relies almost entirely on the fossil fuels that are the main driver of global warming.
item.dc:creator: Max Bearak
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:credit: Nanna Heitmann for The New York Times
item.media:description: An oil site near the COP29 venue on the outskirts of Baku, Azerbaijan.

item.title: COP29 Talks Open in Baku in the Shadow of Trump’s Election
item.description: The election of Donald J. Trump is sapping momentum from global climate talks as diplomats brace for his pro-fossil-fuel agenda.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman

item.title: How Attacks on Israeli Soccer Fans in Amsterdam Unfolded
item.description: Antisemitic assaults on visiting Israeli soccer fans, and incendiary chants and attacks by some Israelis: Here’s what we know so far about the violence in Amsterdam last week.
item.dc:creator: Jim Tankersley
item.media:description: Extra security measures were put in place in Amsterdam after clashes involving supporters of the soccer club Maccabi Tel Aviv.

item.title: Monday Briefing: Russian and North Korean Troops Assemble
item.description: Plus, does tech make us feel lonely?
item.dc:creator: Gaya Gupta
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Ukrainian army vehicle passing through a destroyed Russian border post.

item.title: Saudi Arabia Hosts a Tennis Final Won by Coco Gauff
item.description: The kingdom, which has been accused of trying to “sportswash” its human rights record, hosted the WTA Finals, part of its unstoppable advance into the world of sports.
item.dc:creator: Ismaeel Naar and Vivian Yee
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Coco Gauff of the United States serving to Qinwen Zheng of China during the WTA singles final in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, on Saturday.

item.title: Paul Stephenson, 87, Dies; Advanced Britain’s Civil Rights Movement
item.description: The bus boycott and one-man pub sit-in that he led in the mid-1960s helped pave the way for a law outlawing discrimination in public places.
item.dc:creator: Trip Gabriel
item.media:description: Paul Stephenson in 2005. That year The Independent wrote that his efforts to end discrimination “helped to thrust race into the national limelight and change public opinion about the treatment of Blacks and Asians living in Britain.”

item.title: Israeli Strike in Gaza Kills Over 30 Palestinians, Emergency Services Say
item.description: The strike hit a house in the city of Jabaliya, which has repeatedly come under attack as the Israeli military has pressed an offensive in northern Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Hiba Yazbek
item.media:description: Palestinians surveyed the destruction in Jabaliya, in northern Gaza, on Sunday.

item.title: Russia Says It Shot Down Waves of Ukrainian Drones Above Moscow
item.description: Officials said more than 30 drones had been intercepted over suburban areas of the Russian capital in what was the biggest such attack since the invasion of Ukraine in 2022.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins
item.media:description: Emergency responders at a damaged building after a drone attack in the village of Stanovoye in the Moscow region on Sunday.

item.title: Israeli Strike Kills 23 People North of Beirut, Lebanon Says
item.description: The strike in the Jbeil district of Lebanon came amid an apparent diplomatic push for a cease-fire between Israel and Hezbollah.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Isabel Kershner
item.media:description: Rescuers searching for survivors after an airstrike in the Lebanese village of Almat on Sunday.

item.title: 50,000 Russian and North Korean Troops Mass Ahead of Attack, U.S. Says
item.description: Ukrainian officials expect a counteroffensive in western Russia to begin in the coming days as North Korea’s troops train with Russian forces.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes, Eric Schmitt and Michael Schwirtz
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Ukrainian army vehicle passing through the destroyed Russian border post at the Sudzha crossing and entering Russia in August.

item.title: Trump’s Presidency Could Spell a Lonely and Dangerous Stretch for Europe
item.description: Internal political squabbles — and the fallout from a global backlash to inflation, immigration and ruling elites — are hobbling Germany and France.
item.dc:creator: Jim Tankersley and Aurelien Breeden
item.media:description: President Emmanuel Macron of France, left, and Chancellor Olaf Scholz of Germany in May in Meseberg, near Berlin.

item.title: Palestinians Try to Sway Trump, Reaching Out to Tiffany Trump’s Relative
item.description: The Palestinian leader Mahmoud Abbas has met with Tiffany Trump’s father-in-law and written conciliatory letters to the president-elect, a strong supporter of Israel.
item.dc:creator: Adam Rasgon and Charles Homans
item.media:description: Mahmoud Abbas, the leader of the Palestinian Authority, and then-President Donald J. Trump in the West Bank city of Bethlehem in 2017.

item.title: Han Dongfang, Once China’s ‘Worst Nightmare,’ Refuses to Back Down
item.description: Neither jail nor exile to Hong Kong has stopped Han Dongfang, a former Tiananmen Square protest leader, from championing workers’ rights. “If you’re born stubborn, you go everywhere stubborn.”
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Stevenson
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Anthony Kwan for The New York Times
item.media:description: Han Dongfang is one of China’s last remaining labor rights activists not in hiding.

item.title: Taiwan Sees a Higher Price for U.S. Support as Trump Returns to Power
item.description: The president-elect’s call for Taiwan to spend more on its own defense and his complaints about its semiconductor dominance may herald a tenser relationship.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley and Amy Chang Chien
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: Taiwanese soldiers during military exercises last year. Donald J. Trump has complained about Taiwan, saying: “They don’t pay us money for the protection, you know?”

item.title: Trump Should Not Let Putin Claim Victory in Ukraine, Says NATO Official
item.description: Adm. Rob Bauer warned against any peace deal that was too favorable to Russia, arguing that it could undermine American interests.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes
item.media:description: Admiral Rob Bauer, NATO’s top military official, in September. “It’s important enough to talk about Ukraine on its own, but there is more at stake than just Ukraine,” he said in an interview on Saturday.

item.title: Baltazar Ushca, Who Kept Andean Ice Harvesting Alive, Dies at 80
item.description: He trekked up Ecuador’s tallest mountain twice a week for six decades to hack ice off a glacier with a pickax. He is believed to have been the last of his breed.
item.dc:creator: Richard Sandomir
item.media:description: Baltazar Ushca in an undated photo extracting ice from the glaciers of Mount Chimborazo in Ecuador. He did this work until about five years ago, when he injured his foot.

item.title: Trevor Sorbie, Creator of the Dorothy Hamill ‘Wedge’ Cut, Dies at 75
item.description: He also styled hair for Helen Mirren, the Beach Boys and others, and he was honored by Queen Elizabeth II for services to British hairdressing.
item.dc:creator: Emmett Lindner
item.media:description: The hairdresser Trevor Sorbie in 2017.

item.title: Qatar Pauses Role as Israel-Hamas Mediator in Gaza Cease-Fire Talks
item.description: The Qatari Foreign Ministry announced it had stepped back from talks, saying it would resume once Israel and Hamas “show willingness and seriousness.”
item.dc:creator: Adam Rasgon, Aaron Boxerman and Julian E. Barnes
item.media:description: Doha, Qatar, in October. Qatar has hosted Hamas’s exiled political leaders since 2012, making it a key mediator in the talks to reach a cease-fire in the war in Gaza.
